projectDesc.p: This version of the Folger Digital Texts uses TEI Simple to encode the Shakespeare texts edited by Barbara Mowat and Paul Werstine. The major goal of recasting the texts in this manner is to make them interoperable with a large corpus of early modern texts derived from the EEBO-TCP transcriptions and encoded in TEI Simple with linguistic annotation.

For a full description of the encoding practices of the Folger Digital Texts consult their encodingDesc section. This version is completely faithful to the readings, orthogrgraphy, and punctuation of the source text. It uses a different XML encoding scheme, with occasional losses in expressiveness. The major differences are:
Number div are replaced by unnumbered divs
Lines of verse are marked in l, tags, lines of prose in ab
All xml:ids are corpuswide identifiers
Information from the participant description element particDesc in the teiHeader has been moved into a castList element in the front element
Each spoken word in the text has been linguistically annotated with a lemma and POS tag

refsDecl.p: Words, spaces, and punctuation characters are numbered sequentially, incremented by 10.

Most other elements begin with an element-specific prefix, followed by a reference to the Folger Through Line Number, a sequential numbering of the numbered lines in the text. If an element is inline with play text, it has the same line number as the line where it begins. If it begins on a line following play text, a decimal number is appended and incremented as necessary. If it falls between a speech prefix and the play text, a ".0" is appended to the value of the following line number.

castItem.roleDesc: also known as Don Adriano de Armado
Armado’s Page, also known as Mote

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Ferdinand, King of Navarre, Berowne, Longaville, and Dumaine.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Let fame, that all hunt after in their lives,
Live registered upon our brazen tombs,
And then grace us in the disgrace of death,
When, spite of cormorant devouring time,
Th’ endeavor of this present breath may buy
That honor which shall bate his scythe’s keen edge
And make us heirs of all eternity.
Therefore, brave conquerors, for so you are
That war against your own affections
And the huge army of the world’s desires,
Our late edict shall strongly stand in force.
Navarre shall be the wonder of the world;
Our court shall be a little academe,
Still and contemplative in living art.
You three, Berowne, Dumaine, and Longaville,
Have sworn for three years’ term to live with me,
My fellow scholars, and to keep those statutes
That are recorded in this schedule here.
Your oaths are passed, and now subscribe your names,
That his own hand may strike his honor down
That violates the smallest branch herein.
If you are armed to do as sworn to do,
Subscribe to your deep oaths, and keep it too.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: I am resolved. ’Tis but a three years’ fast.
The mind shall banquet though the body pine.
Fat paunches have lean pates, and dainty bits
Make rich the ribs but bankrout quite the wits.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: My loving lord, Dumaine is mortified.
The grosser manner of these world’s delights
He throws upon the gross world’s baser slaves.
To love, to wealth, to pomp I pine and die,
With all these living in philosophy.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: I can but say their protestation over.
So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,
That is, to live and study here three years.
But there are other strict observances:
As not to see a woman in that term,
Which I hope well is not enrollèd there;
And one day in a week to touch no food,
And but one meal on every day besides,
The which I hope is not enrollèd there;
And then to sleep but three hours in the night,
And not be seen to wink of all the day—
When I was wont to think no harm all night,
And make a dark night too of half the day—
Which I hope well is not enrollèd there.
O, these are barren tasks, too hard to keep,
Not to see ladies, study, fast, not sleep.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Your oath is passed to pass away from these.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Let me say no, my liege, an if you please.
I only swore to study with your Grace
And stay here in your court for three years’ space.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: By yea and nay, sir. Then I swore in jest.
What is the end of study, let me know?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Why, that to know which else we should not know.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Things hid and barred, you mean, from common sense.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Ay, that is study’s godlike recompense.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Come on, then, I will swear to study so,
To know the thing I am forbid to know:

lg.l: As thus— to study where I well may dine,
When I to feast expressly am forbid;
Or study where to meet some mistress fine
When mistresses from common sense are hid;
Or having sworn too hard-a-keeping oath,
Study to break it, and not break my troth.
If study’s gain be thus, and this be so,
Study knows that which yet it doth not know.

sp.l: Swear me to this, and I will ne’er say no.

lg.l: These be the stops that hinder study quite,
And train our intellects to vain delight.
Why, all delights are vain, and that most vain
Which with pain purchased doth inherit pain:
As painfully to pore upon a book
To seek the light of truth, while truth the while
Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look.
Light seeking light doth light of light beguile.
So, ere you find where light in darkness lies,
Your light grows dark by losing of your eyes.
Study me how to please the eye indeed
By fixing it upon a fairer eye,
Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed
And give him light that it was blinded by.
Study is like the heaven’s glorious sun,
That will not be deep-searched with saucy looks.
Small have continual plodders ever won,
Save base authority from others’ books.
These earthly godfathers of heaven’s lights,
That give a name to every fixèd star,
Have no more profit of their shining nights
Than those that walk and wot not what they are.
Too much to know is to know naught but fame,
And every godfather can give a name.
How well he’s read to reason against reading.
Proceeded well, to stop all good proceeding.
He weeds the corn, and still lets grow the weeding.
The spring is near when green geese are a-breeding.
How follows that?
Fit in his place and time.
In reason nothing.
Something then in rhyme.
Berowne is like an envious sneaping frost
That bites the firstborn infants of the spring.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE

lg.l: Well, say I am. Why should proud summer boast
Before the birds have any cause to sing?

sp.l: Why should I joy in any abortive birth?

lg.l: At Christmas I no more desire a rose
Than wish a snow in May’s new-fangled shows,
But like of each thing that in season grows.
So you, to study now it is too late,
Climb o’er the house to unlock the little gate.
Well, sit you out. Go home, Berowne. Adieu.
No, my good lord, I have sworn to stay with you.
And though I have for barbarism spoke more
Than for that angel knowledge you can say,
Yet, confident, I’ll keep what I have sworn
And bide the penance of each three years’ day.
Give me the paper. Let me read the same,
And to the strictest decrees I’ll write my name.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: How well this yielding rescues thee from shame.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
Item, That no woman shall come within
a mile of my court. Hath this been proclaimed?

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p: Four days ago.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
Let’s see the penalty. Reads: On pain of
losing her tongue. Who devised this penalty?

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p: Marry, that did I.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Sweet lord, and why?

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: To fright them hence with that dread penalty.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: A dangerous law against gentility.

p.q:
Item, If any man be seen to talk with a
woman within the term of three years, he shall endure
such public shame as the rest of the court can possible
devise.

lg.l: This article, my liege, yourself must break,
For well you know here comes in embassy
The French king’s daughter with yourself to speak—
A maid of grace and complete majesty—
About surrender up of Aquitaine
To her decrepit, sick, and bedrid father.
Therefore this article is made in vain,
Or vainly comes th’ admirèd princess hither.
What say you, lords? Why, this was quite forgot.
So study evermore is overshot.
While it doth study to have what it would,
It doth forget to do the thing it should.
And when it hath the thing it hunteth most,
’Tis won as towns with fire— so won, so lost.
We must of force dispense with this decree.
She must lie here on mere necessity.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE

lg.l: Necessity will make us all forsworn
Three thousand times within this three years’ space;
For every man with his affects is born,
Not by might mastered, but by special grace.
If I break faith, this word shall speak for me:
I am forsworn on mere necessity.
So to the laws at large I write my name,
And he that breaks them in the least degree
Stands in attainder of eternal shame.
Suggestions are to other as to me,
But I believe, although I seem so loath,
I am the last that will last keep his oath.

sp.l: But is there no quick recreation granted?

lg.l: Ay, that there is. Our court, you know, is haunted
With a refinèd traveler of Spain,
A man in all the world’s new fashion planted,
That hath a mint of phrases in his brain;
One who the music of his own vain tongue
Doth ravish like enchanting harmony,
A man of compliments, whom right and wrong
Have chose as umpire of their mutiny.
This child of fancy, that Armado hight,
For interim to our studies shall relate
In high-born words the worth of many a knight
From tawny Spain lost in the world’s debate.
How you delight, my lords, I know not, I,
But I protest I love to hear him lie,
And I will use him for my minstrelsy.
Armado is a most illustrious wight,
A man of fire-new words, fashion’s own knight.
Costard the swain and he shall be our sport,
And so to study three years is but short.

div.stage: Enter Dull, a Constable, with a letter, and Costard.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p: Which is the Duke’s own person?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: This, fellow. What wouldst?

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
I myself reprehend his own person, for I am his
Grace’s farborough. But I would see his own
person in flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: This is he.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
Signior Arm-, Arm-, commends you.
There’s villainy abroad. This letter will tell you
more.

div.stage: He gives the letter to the King.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching
me.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: A letter from the magnificent Armado.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
How low soever the matter, I hope in God
for high words.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p:
A high hope for a low heaven. God grant
us patience!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: To hear, or forbear hearing?

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p:
To hear meekly, sir, and to laugh moderately,
or to forbear both.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause
to climb in the merriness.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
The matter is to me, sir, as concerning
Jaquenetta. The manner of it is, I was taken with
the manner.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: In what manner?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
In manner and form following, sir, all those
three. I was seen with her in the manor house,
sitting with her upon the form, and taken following
her into the park, which, put together, is “ in manner
and form following.” Now, sir, for the manner.
It is the manner of a man to speak to a woman. For
the form— in some form.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: For the “ following,” sir?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
As it shall follow in my correction, and God
defend the right.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Will you hear this letter with attention?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: As we would hear an oracle.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Such is the sinplicity of man to hearken after
the flesh.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q:
Great deputy, the welkin’s vicegerent and
sole dominator of Navarre, my soul’s earth’s god, and
body’s fost’ring patron—

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Not a word of Costard yet.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
It may be so, but if he say it is so, he is, in
telling true, but so.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Be to me, and every man that dares not fight.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: No words.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Of other men’s secrets, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q:
So it is, besieged with sable-colored melancholy,
I did commend the black oppressing humor
to the most wholesome physic of thy health-giving air;
and, as I am a gentleman, betook myself to walk. The
time when? About the sixth hour, when beasts most
graze, birds best peck, and men sit down to that
nourishment which is called supper. So much for the
time when. Now for the ground which— which, I
mean, I walked upon. It is yclept thy park. Then for the
place where— where, I mean, I did encounter that
obscene and most prepost’rous event that draweth
from my snow-white pen the ebon-colored ink, which
here thou viewest, beholdest, surveyest, or seest. But to
the place where. It standeth north-north-east and by
east from the west corner of thy curious-knotted
garden. There did I see that low-spirited swain, that
base minnow of thy mirth,—

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Still me?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q: which, as I remember, hight Costard,—

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: O, me!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q:
sorted and consorted, contrary to thy
established proclaimed edict and continent canon,
which with— O with— but with this I passion to say
wherewith—

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: With a wench.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q:
with a child of our grandmother Eve, a
female; or, for thy more sweet understanding, a
woman: him, I, as my ever-esteemed duty pricks
me on, have sent to thee, to receive the meed of
punishment by thy sweet Grace’s officer, Anthony
Dull, a man of good repute, carriage, bearing, and
estimation.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p: Me, an ’t shall please you. I am Anthony Dull.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.q:
For Jaquenetta— so is the weaker vessel
called which I apprehended with the aforesaid
swain— I keep her as a vessel of thy law’s fury, and
shall, at the least of thy sweet notice, bring her to trial.
Thine, in all compliments of devoted and heartburning
heat of duty,
Don Adriano de Armado.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
This is not so well as I looked for, but the
best that ever I heard.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Ay, the best, for the worst. To Costard. But,
sirrah, what say you to this?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Sir, I confess the wench.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Did you hear the proclamation?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I do confess much of the hearing it, but little
of the marking of it.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
It was proclaimed a year’s imprisonment to be
taken with a wench.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I was taken with none, sir. I was taken with a
damsel.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Well, it was proclaimed “ damsel.”

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
This was no damsel neither, sir. She was a
virgin.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
It is so varied too, for it was proclaimed
“ virgin.”

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
If it were, I deny her virginity. I was taken
with a maid.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: This “ maid” will not serve your turn, sir.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: This maid will serve my turn, sir.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p:
Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall
fast a week with bran and water.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I had rather pray a month with mutton and
porridge.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: And Don Armado shall be your keeper.
sp.l: My Lord Berowne, see him delivered o’er,

lg.l: And go we, lords, to put in practice that
Which each to other hath so strongly sworn.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE

lg.l: I’ll lay my head to any goodman’s hat,
These oaths and laws will prove an idle scorn.

sp.l: Sirrah, come on.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I suffer for the truth, sir; for true it is I was
taken with Jaquenetta, and Jaquenetta is a true
girl. And therefore welcome the sour cup of prosperity.
Affliction may one day smile again, and till
then, sit thee down, sorrow.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Armado and Mote, his page.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit
grows melancholy?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: A great sign, sir, that he will look sad.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Why, sadness is one and the selfsame thing,
dear imp.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: No, no. O Lord, sir, no!

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
How canst thou part sadness and melancholy,
my tender juvenal?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
By a familiar demonstration of the working, my
tough signior.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Why “ tough signior”? Why “ tough signior”?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Why “ tender juvenal”? Why “ tender juvenal”?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I spoke it “ tender juvenal” as a congruent
epitheton appertaining to thy young days, which
we may nominate “ tender.”

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
And I “ tough signior” as an appurtenant title to
your old time, which we may name “ tough.”

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Pretty and apt.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
How mean you, sir? I pretty and my saying apt, or
I apt and my saying pretty?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Thou pretty because little.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Little pretty, because little. Wherefore apt?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: And therefore apt, because quick.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Speak you this in my praise, master?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: In thy condign praise.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I will praise an eel with the same praise.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: What, that an eel is ingenious?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: That an eel is quick.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I do say thou art quick in answers. Thou
heat’st my blood.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I am answered, sir.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I love not to be crossed.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
He speaks the mere contrary; crosses love
not him.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I have promised to study three years with the
Duke.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: You may do it in an hour, sir.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: How many is one thrice told?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I am ill at reckoning. It fitteth the spirit of a
tapster.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: You are a gentleman and a gamester, sir.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I confess both. They are both the varnish of a
complete man.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Then I am sure you know how much the gross
sum of deuce-ace amounts to.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: It doth amount to one more than two.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Which the base vulgar do call “ three.”

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Why, sir, is this such a piece of study? Now here is
“ three” studied ere you’ll thrice wink. And how
easy it is to put “ years” to the word “ three” and
study “ three years” in two words, the dancing horse
will tell you.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: A most fine figure.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: To prove you a cipher.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I will hereupon confess I am in love; and as it
is base for a soldier to love, so am I in love with a
base wench. If drawing my sword against the
humor of affection would deliver me from the
reprobate thought of it, I would take desire prisoner
and ransom him to any French courtier for a
new-devised curtsy. I think scorn to sigh; methinks
I should outswear Cupid. Comfort me, boy. What
great men have been in love?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Hercules, master.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Most sweet Hercules! More authority, dear
boy, name more; and, sweet my child, let them be
men of good repute and carriage.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Samson, master; he was a man of good carriage,
great carriage, for he carried the town gates on his
back like a porter, and he was in love.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
O, well-knit Samson, strong-jointed Samson;
I do excel thee in my rapier as much as thou didst
me in carrying gates. I am in love too. Who was
Samson’s love, my dear Mote?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: A woman, master.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Of what complexion?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Of all the four, or the three, or the two, or one of
the four.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Tell me precisely of what complexion.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Of the sea-water green, sir.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Is that one of the four complexions?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: As I have read, sir, and the best of them too.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Green indeed is the color of lovers. But to
have a love of that color, methinks Samson had
small reason for it. He surely affected her for her
wit.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: It was so, sir, for she had a green wit.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: My love is most immaculate white and red.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Most maculate thoughts, master, are masked
under such colors.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Define, define, well-educated infant.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
My father’s wit and my mother’s tongue, assist
me.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Sweet invocation of a child, most pretty and
pathetical.

sp.speaker: BOY

lg.l: If she be made of white and red,
Her faults will ne’er be known,
For blushing cheeks by faults are bred,
And fears by pale white shown.
Then if she fear, or be to blame,
By this you shall not know,
For still her cheeks possess the same
Which native she doth owe.

sp.p:
A dangerous rhyme, master, against the reason of
white and red.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Is there not a ballad, boy, of The King and
the Beggar?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
The world was very guilty of such a ballad some
three ages since, but I think now ’tis not to be found;
or if it were, it would neither serve for the writing
nor the tune.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I will have that subject newly writ o’er, that I
may example my digression by some mighty precedent.
Boy, I do love that country girl that I took in
the park with the rational hind Costard. She deserves
well.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
To be whipped— and yet a better love than
my master.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Sing, boy. My spirit grows heavy in love.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
And that’s great marvel, loving a light
wench.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I say sing.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Forbear till this company be past.

div.stage: Enter Clown ( Costard,) Constable ( Dull,) and Wench( Jaquenetta.)

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
Sir, the Duke’s pleasure is that you
keep Costard safe, and you must suffer him to take
no delight, nor no penance, but he must fast three
days a week. For this damsel, I must keep her at the
park. She is allowed for the dey-woman. Fare you
well.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I do betray myself with blushing.—
Maid.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: Man.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I will visit thee at the lodge.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: That’s hereby.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I know where it is situate.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: Lord, how wise you are.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I will tell thee wonders.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: With that face?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I love thee.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: So I heard you say.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: And so, farewell.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p: Fair weather after you.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p: Come, Jaquenetta, away.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Villain, thou shalt fast for thy
offenses ere thou be pardoned.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Well, sir, I hope when I do it I shall do it on
a full stomach.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Thou shalt be heavily punished.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I am more bound to you than your fellows,
for they are but lightly rewarded.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Take away this villain. Shut him up.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Come, you transgressing slave, away.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Let me not be pent up, sir. I will
fast being loose.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
No, sir, that were fast and loose. Thou shalt to
prison.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Well, if ever I do see the merry days of
desolation that I have seen, some shall see.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: What shall some see?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Nay, nothing, Master Mote, but what they
look upon. It is not for prisoners to be too silent in
their words, and therefore I will say nothing. I thank
God I have as little patience as another man, and
therefore I can be quiet.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I do affect the very ground ( which is base)
where her shoe ( which is baser) guided by her foot
( which is basest) doth tread. I shall be forsworn
( which is a great argument of falsehood) if I love.
And how can that be true love which is falsely
attempted? Love is a familiar; love is a devil. There is
no evil angel but love, yet was Samson so tempted,
and he had an excellent strength; yet was Solomon
so seduced, and he had a very good wit. Cupid’s
butt-shaft is too hard for Hercules’ club, and therefore
too much odds for a Spaniard’s rapier. The first
and second cause will not serve my turn; the
passado he respects not, the duello he regards not.
His disgrace is to be called “ boy,” but his glory is to
subdue men. Adieu, valor; rust, rapier; be still,
drum, for your manager is in love. Yea, he loveth.
Assist me, some extemporal god of rhyme, for I am
sure I shall turn sonnet. Devise wit, write pen, for I
am for whole volumes in folio.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the Princess of France, with three attending Ladies ( Rosaline, Maria, and Katherine), Boyet and other Lords.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Now, madam, summon up your dearest spirits.
Consider who the King your father sends,
To whom he sends, and what’s his embassy.
Yourself, held precious in the world’s esteem,
To parley with the sole inheritor
Of all perfections that a man may owe,
Matchless Navarre; the plea of no less weight
Than Aquitaine, a dowry for a queen.
Be now as prodigal of all dear grace
As nature was in making graces dear
When she did starve the general world besides
And prodigally gave them all to you.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Good Lord Boyet, my beauty, though but mean,
Needs not the painted flourish of your praise.
Beauty is bought by judgment of the eye,
Not uttered by base sale of chapmen’s tongues.
I am less proud to hear you tell my worth
Than you much willing to be counted wise
In spending your wit in the praise of mine.
But now to task the tasker: good Boyet,
You are not ignorant all-telling fame
Doth noise abroad Navarre hath made a vow,
Till painful study shall outwear three years,
No woman may approach his silent court.
Therefore to ’s seemeth it a needful course,
Before we enter his forbidden gates,
To know his pleasure, and in that behalf,
Bold of your worthiness, we single you
As our best-moving fair solicitor.
Tell him the daughter of the King of France
On serious business craving quick dispatch,
Importunes personal conference with his Grace.
Haste, signify so much, while we attend,
Like humble-visaged suitors, his high will.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Proud of employment, willingly I go.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: All pride is willing pride, and yours is so.
Who are the votaries, my loving lords,
That are vow-fellows with this virtuous duke?

sp.speaker: A LORD
sp.l: Lord Longaville is one.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Know you the man?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: I know him, madam. At a marriage feast
Between Lord Perigort and the beauteous heir
Of Jaques Falconbridge, solemnizèd
In Normandy, saw I this Longaville.
A man of sovereign parts he is esteemed,
Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms.
Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
The only soil of his fair virtue’s gloss,
If virtue’s gloss will stain with any soil,
Is a sharp wit matched with too blunt a will,
Whose edge hath power to cut, whose will still wills
It should none spare that come within his power.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Some merry mocking lord, belike. Is ’t so?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: They say so most that most his humors know.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Such short-lived wits do wither as they grow.
Who are the rest?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: The young Dumaine, a well-accomplished youth,
Of all that virtue love for virtue loved.
Most power to do most harm, least knowing ill;
For he hath wit to make an ill shape good,
And shape to win grace though he had no wit.
I saw him at the Duke Alanson’s once,
And much too little of that good I saw
Is my report to his great worthiness.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Another of these students at that time
Was there with him, if I have heard a truth.
Berowne they call him, but a merrier man,
Within the limit of becoming mirth,
I never spent an hour’s talk withal.
His eye begets occasion for his wit,
For every object that the one doth catch
The other turns to a mirth-moving jest,
Which his fair tongue, conceit’s expositor,
Delivers in such apt and gracious words
That agèd ears play truant at his tales,
And younger hearings are quite ravishèd,
So sweet and voluble is his discourse.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: God bless my ladies, are they all in love,
That every one her own hath garnishèd
With such bedecking ornaments of praise?

sp.speaker: A LORD
sp.l: Here comes Boyet.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Now, what admittance, lord?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Navarre had notice of your fair approach,
And he and his competitors in oath
Were all addressed to meet you, gentle lady,
Before I came. Marry, thus much I have learned:
He rather means to lodge you in the field,
Like one that comes here to besiege his court,
Than seek a dispensation for his oath
To let you enter his unpeopled house.
sp.stage: Enter King of Navarre, Longaville, Dumaine, and Berowne.
sp.l: Here comes Navarre.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Fair Princess, welcome to the court of Navarre.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p:
“ Fair” I give you back again, and “ welcome”
I have not yet. The roof of this court is too
high to be yours, and welcome to the wide fields too
base to be mine.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: You shall be welcome, madam, to my court.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: I will be welcome, then. Conduct me thither.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Hear me, dear lady. I have sworn an oath.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Our Lady help my lord! He’ll be forsworn.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Why, will shall break it, will and nothing else.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Your Ladyship is ignorant what it is.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Were my lord so, his ignorance were wise,
Where now his knowledge must prove ignorance.
I hear your Grace hath sworn out housekeeping.
’Tis deadly sin to keep that oath, my lord,
And sin to break it.
But pardon me, I am too sudden bold.
To teach a teacher ill beseemeth me.
Vouchsafe to read the purpose of my coming,
And suddenly resolve me in my suit.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Madam, I will, if suddenly I may.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: You will the sooner that I were away,
For you’ll prove perjured if you make me stay.

div.stage: They walk aside while the King reads the paper.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Did not I dance with you in Brabant once?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: I know you did.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: How needless was it then
To ask the question.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: You must not be so quick.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: ’Tis long of you that spur me with such questions.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Your wit’s too hot, it speeds too fast; ’twill tire.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: What time o’ day?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: The hour that fools should ask.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Now fair befall your mask.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Fair fall the face it covers.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: And send you many lovers.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Amen, so you be none.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Nay, then, will I be gone.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Madam, your father here doth intimate
The payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
Being but the one half of an entire sum
Disbursèd by my father in his wars.
But say that he or we, as neither have,
Received that sum, yet there remains unpaid
A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which
One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
Although not valued to the money’s worth.
If then the King your father will restore
But that one half which is unsatisfied,
We will give up our right in Aquitaine,
And hold fair friendship with his Majesty.
But that, it seems, he little purposeth;
For here he doth demand to have repaid
A hundred thousand crowns, and not demands,
On payment of a hundred thousand crowns,
To have his title live in Aquitaine—
Which we much rather had depart withal,
And have the money by our father lent,
Than Aquitaine, so gelded as it is.
Dear Princess, were not his requests so far
From reason’s yielding, your fair self should make
A yielding ’gainst some reason in my breast,
And go well satisfied to France again.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: You do the King my father too much wrong,
And wrong the reputation of your name,
In so unseeming to confess receipt
Of that which hath so faithfully been paid.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I do protest I never heard of it;
And if you prove it, I’ll repay it back
Or yield up Aquitaine.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: We arrest your word.—
Boyet, you can produce acquittances
For such a sum from special officers
Of Charles his father.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Satisfy me so.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: So please your Grace, the packet is not come
Where that and other specialties are bound.
Tomorrow you shall have a sight of them.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: It shall suffice me; at which interview
All liberal reason I will yield unto.
Meantime receive such welcome at my hand
As honor ( without breach of honor) may
Make tender of to thy true worthiness.
You may not come, fair princess, within my gates,
But here without you shall be so received
As you shall deem yourself lodged in my heart,
Though so denied fair harbor in my house.
Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell.
Tomorrow shall we visit you again.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Sweet health and fair desires consort your Grace.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.

div.stage: He exits with Dumaine, Longaville, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
Lady, I will commend you to
my own heart.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p:
Pray you, do my commendations. I would
be glad to see it.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: I would you heard it groan.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p: Is the fool sick?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Sick at the heart.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p: Alack, let it blood.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Would that do it good?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p: My physic says “ ay.”

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Will you prick ’t with your eye?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p: No point, with my knife.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Now God save thy life.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p: And yours from long living.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: I cannot stay thanksgiving.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: Sir, I pray you, a word. What lady is that same?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: The heir of Alanson, Katherine her name.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: A gallant lady, monsieur. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: I beseech you, a word. What is she in the white?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: A woman sometimes, an you saw her in the light.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: Perchance light in the light. I desire her name.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: She hath but one for herself; to desire that were a shame.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p: Pray you, sir, whose daughter?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p: Her mother’s, I have heard.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p: God’s blessing on your beard!

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p:
Good sir, be not offended. She is an heir of
Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.p:
Nay, my choler is ended. She is a most
sweet lady.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p: Not unlike, sir, that may be.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: What’s her name in the cap?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p: Rosaline, by good hap.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Is she wedded or no?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p: To her will, sir, or so.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: You are welcome, sir. Adieu.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p: Farewell to me, sir, and welcome to you.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: That last is Berowne, the merry madcap lord.
Not a word with him but a jest.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: And every jest but a word.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: It was well done of you to take him at his word.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: I was as willing to grapple as he was to board.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Two hot sheeps, marry.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: And wherefore not ships?
No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: You sheep and I pasture. Shall that finish the jest?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: So you grant pasture for me.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: Not so, gentle beast,
My lips are no common, though several they be.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Belonging to whom?

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: To my fortunes and me.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Good wits will be jangling; but, gentles, agree,
This civil war of wits were much better used
On Navarre and his bookmen, for here ’tis abused.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: If my observation, which very seldom lies,
By the heart’s still rhetoric, disclosèd wi’ th’ eyes,
Deceive me not now, Navarre is infected.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: With what?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: With that which we lovers entitle “ affected.”

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Why, all his behaviors did make their retire
To the court of his eye, peeping thorough desire.
His heart like an agate with your print impressed,
Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed.
His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
All senses to that sense did make their repair,
To feel only looking on fairest of fair.
Methought all his senses were locked in his eye,
As jewels in crystal for some prince to buy,
Who, tend’ring their own worth from where they were glassed,
Did point you to buy them along as you passed.
His face’s own margent did quote such amazes
That all eyes saw his eyes enchanted with gazes.
I’ll give you Aquitaine, and all that is his,
An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Come, to our pavilion. Boyet is disposed.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: But to speak that in words which his eye hath disclosed.
I only have made a mouth of his eye
By adding a tongue which I know will not lie.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: Thou art an old lovemonger and speakest skillfully.

sp.speaker: KATHERINE
sp.l: He is Cupid’s grandfather, and learns news of him.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Then was Venus like her mother, for her father is but grim.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Do you hear, my mad wenches?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: What then, do you see?

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: Ay, our way to be gone.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: You are too hard for me.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter Braggart Armado and his Boy.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Warble, child, make passionate my sense of
hearing.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Concolinel.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Sweet air. Go, tenderness of years.

Take this key, give enlargement to the
swain, bring him festinately hither. I must employ
him in a letter to my love.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Master, will you win your love with a French
brawl?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: How meanest thou? Brawling in French?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
No, my complete master, but to jig off a tune at the
tongue’s end, canary to it with your feet, humor it
with turning up your eyelids, sigh a note and sing a
note, sometimes through the throat as if you
swallowed love with singing love, sometimes
through the nose as if you snuffed up love by
smelling love; with your hat penthouse-like o’er the
shop of your eyes, with your arms crossed on your
thin-belly doublet like a rabbit on a spit; or your
hands in your pocket like a man after the old
painting; and keep not too long in one tune, but a
snip and away. These are compliments, these are
humors; these betray nice wenches that would be
betrayed without these, and make them men of
note— do you note me?— that most are affected
to these.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: How hast thou purchased this experience?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: By my penny of observation.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: But O— but O—.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: “ The hobby-horse is forgot.”

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Call’st thou my love “ hobby-horse”?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: No, master. The hobby-horse is but a colt,

and your love perhaps a hackney.— But have you
forgot your love?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Almost I had.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Negligent student, learn her by heart.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: By heart and in heart, boy.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
And out of heart, master. All those three I will
prove.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
A man, if I live; and this “ by, in, and without,”
upon the instant: “ by” heart you love her, because
your heart cannot come by her; “ in” heart you love
her, because your heart is in love with her; and
“ out” of heart you love her, being out of heart that
you cannot enjoy her.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: I am all these three.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
And three times as much more, aside and yet
nothing at all.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
Fetch hither the swain. He must carry me a
letter.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
A message well sympathized— a horse to be ambassador
for an ass.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Ha? Ha? What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
Marry, sir, you must send the ass upon the horse,
for he is very slow-gaited. But I go.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: The way is but short. Away!

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: As swift as lead, sir.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: Thy meaning, pretty ingenious?
Is not lead a metal heavy, dull, and slow?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Minime, honest master, or rather, master, no.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: I say lead is slow.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: You are too swift, sir, to say so.
Is that lead slow which is fired from a gun?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: Sweet smoke of rhetoric!
He reputes me a cannon, and the bullet, that’s he.—
I shoot thee at the swain.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Thump, then, and I flee.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: A most acute juvenal, voluble and free of grace.
By thy favor, sweet welkin, I must sigh in thy face.
Most rude melancholy, valor gives thee place.
My herald is returned.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: A wonder, master!
Here’s a costard broken in a shin.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: Some enigma, some riddle. Come, thy l’envoi begin.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
No egma, no riddle, no l’envoi, no salve in
the mail, sir. O, sir, plantain, a plain plantain! No
l’envoi, no l’envoi, no salve, sir, but a plantain.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
By virtue, thou enforcest laughter; thy silly
thought, my spleen. The heaving of my lungs
provokes me to ridiculous smiling. O pardon me,
my stars! Doth the inconsiderate take salve for
l’envoi, and the word l’envoi for a salve?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Do the wise think them other? Is not l’envoi a salve?

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: No, page, it is an epilogue or discourse to make plain
Some obscure precedence that hath tofore been sain.
I will example it:
The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.
There’s the moral. Now the l’envoi.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I will add the l’envoi. Say the moral again.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: Until the goose came out of door
And stayed the odds by adding four.
sp.p:
Now will I begin your moral, and do you follow with
my l’envoi.
sp.l: The fox, the ape, and the humble-bee
Were still at odds, being but three.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: Until the goose came out of door,
Staying the odds by adding four.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p:
A good l’envoi, ending in the goose. Would you
desire more?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: The boy hath sold him a bargain— a goose, that’s flat.—
Sir, your pennyworth is good, an your goose be fat.
To sell a bargain well is as cunning as fast and loose.
Let me see: a fat l’envoi— ay, that’s a fat goose.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.l: Come hither, come hither. How did this argument begin?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.l: By saying that a costard was broken in a shin.
Then called you for the l’envoi.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
True, and I for a plantain. Thus came your
argument in. Then the boy’s fat l’envoi, the goose
that you bought; and he ended the market.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
But tell me, how was there a costard broken
in a shin?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: I will tell you sensibly.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Thou hast no feeling of it, Mote. I will speak
that l’envoi.
sp.l: I, Costard, running out, that was safely within,
Fell over the threshold and broke my shin.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: We will talk no more of this matter.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Till there be more matter in the shin.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p: Sirrah Costard, I will enfranchise thee.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
O, marry me to one Frances! I smell some
l’envoi, some goose, in this.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
By my sweet soul, I mean, setting thee at
liberty, enfreedoming thy person. Thou wert immured,
restrained, captivated, bound.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
True, true; and now you will be my purgation,
and let me loose.

sp.speaker: ARMADO
sp.p:
I give thee thy liberty, set thee from durance,
and, in lieu thereof, impose on thee nothing but
this: bear this significant to the country maid
Jaquenetta. ( He gives him a paper.) There is remuneration
( giving him a coin,) for the best ward of
mine honor is rewarding my dependents.— Mote,
follow.

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Like the sequel, I. Signior Costard, adieu.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: My sweet ounce of man’s flesh, my incony Jew!
sp.p: Now will I look to his remuneration.

“ Remuneration”! O, that’s the Latin word for
three farthings. Three farthings— remuneration.
“ What’s the price of this inkle?” “ One penny.” “ No,
I’ll give you a remuneration.” Why, it carries it!
Remuneration. Why, it is a fairer name than “ French
crown.” I will never buy and sell out of this word.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
My good knave Costard, exceedingly well
met.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Pray you, sir, how much carnation ribbon
may a man buy for a remuneration?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: What is a remuneration?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Marry, sir, halfpenny farthing.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Why then, three farthing worth of silk.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: I thank your Worship. God be wi’ you.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Stay, slave, I must employ thee.
As thou wilt win my favor, good my knave,
Do one thing for me that I shall entreat.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: When would you have it done, sir?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: This afternoon.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Well, I will do it, sir. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Thou knowest not what it is.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: I shall know, sir, when I have done it.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p: Why, villain, thou must know first.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I will come to your Worship tomorrow
morning.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
It must be done this afternoon. Hark, slave,
it is but this:
sp.l: The Princess comes to hunt here in the park,
And in her train there is a gentle lady.
When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
And Rosaline they call her. Ask for her,
And to her white hand see thou do commend
This sealed-up counsel. There’s thy guerdon.
Go.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Gardon. He looks at the money. O sweet
gardon! Better than remuneration, a ’levenpence
farthing better! Most sweet gardon. I will do it, sir,
in print. Gardon! Remuneration!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: And I forsooth in love! I that have been love’s whip,
A very beadle to a humorous sigh,
A critic, nay, a nightwatch constable,
A domineering pedant o’er the boy,
Than whom no mortal so magnificent.
This wimpled, whining, purblind, wayward boy,
This Signior Junior, giant dwarf, Dan Cupid,
Regent of love rhymes, lord of folded arms,
Th’ anointed sovereign of sighs and groans,
Liege of all loiterers and malcontents,
Dread prince of plackets, king of codpieces,
Sole imperator and great general
Of trotting paritors— O my little heart!
And I to be a corporal of his field
And wear his colors like a tumbler’s hoop!
What? I love, I sue, I seek a wife?
A woman, that is like a German clock,
Still a-repairing, ever out of frame,
And never going aright, being a watch,
But being watched that it may still go right.
Nay, to be perjured, which is worst of all.
And, among three, to love the worst of all,
A whitely wanton with a velvet brow,
With two pitch-balls stuck in her face for eyes.
Ay, and by heaven, one that will do the deed
Though Argus were her eunuch and her guard.
And I to sigh for her, to watch for her,
To pray for her! Go to. It is a plague
That Cupid will impose for my neglect
Of his almighty dreadful little might.
Well, I will love, write, sigh, pray, sue, groan.
Some men must love my lady, and some Joan.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: Enter the Princess, a Forester, her Ladies, Boyet and her other Lords.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Was that the King that spurred his horse so hard
Against the steep uprising of the hill?

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.l: I know not, but I think it was not he.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Whoe’er he was, he showed a mounting mind.—
Well, lords, today we shall have our dispatch.
Or Saturday we will return to France.—
Then, forester, my friend, where is the bush
That we must stand and play the murderer in?

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.l: Hereby, upon the edge of yonder coppice,
A stand where you may make the fairest shoot.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: I thank my beauty, I am fair that shoot,
And thereupon thou speakst “ the fairest shoot.”

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.l: Pardon me, madam, for I meant not so.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: What, what? First praise me, and again say no?
O short-lived pride. Not fair? Alack, for woe!

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.l: Yes, madam, fair.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Nay, never paint me now.
Where fair is not, praise cannot mend the brow.
Here, good my glass, take this for telling true.
Fair payment for foul words is more than due.

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.l: Nothing but fair is that which you inherit.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: See, see, my beauty will be saved by merit.
O heresy in fair, fit for these days!
A giving hand, though foul, shall have fair praise.
But come, the bow. He hands her a bow. Now mercy goes to kill,
And shooting well is then accounted ill.
Thus will I save my credit in the shoot:
Not wounding, pity would not let me do ’t;
If wounding, then it was to show my skill,
That more for praise than purpose meant to kill.
And out of question so it is sometimes:
Glory grows guilty of detested crimes,
When for fame’s sake, for praise, an outward part,
We bend to that the working of the heart;
As I for praise alone now seek to spill
The poor deer’s blood, that my heart means no ill.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Do not curst wives hold that self sovereignty
Only for praise’ sake when they strive to be
Lords o’er their lords?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Only for praise; and praise we may afford
To any lady that subdues a lord.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Here comes a member of the commonwealth.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
God dig-you-den all! Pray you, which is the
head lady?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p:
Thou shalt know her, fellow, by the rest that
have no heads.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Which is the greatest lady, the highest?

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: The thickest and the tallest.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: The thickest and the tallest: it is so, truth is truth.
An your waist, mistress, were as slender as my wit,
One o’ these maids’ girdles for your waist should be fit.
Are not you the chief woman? You are the thickest here.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.p: What’s your will, sir? What’s your will?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
I have a letter from Monsieur Berowne to
one Lady Rosaline.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: O, thy letter, thy letter! He’s a good friend of mine.
Stand aside, good bearer.— Boyet, you can carve.
Break up this capon.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: I am bound to serve.
This letter is mistook; it importeth none here.
It is writ to Jaquenetta.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: We will read it, I swear.
Break the neck of the wax, and everyone give ear.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.q:
By heaven, that thou art fair is most
infallible, true that thou art beauteous, truth itself
that thou art lovely. More fairer than fair, beautiful
than beauteous, truer than truth itself, have commiseration
on thy heroical vassal. The magnanimous and
most illustrate King Cophetua set eye upon the pernicious
and indubitate beggar Zenelophon; and he it
was that might rightly say “ Veni, vidi, vici,” which to
annothanize in the vulgar ( O base and obscure vulgar!)
videlicet, “ He came, see, and overcame”: He
came, one; see, two; overcame, three. Who came? The
King. Why did he come? To see. Why did he see? To
overcome. To whom came he? To the beggar. What
saw he? The beggar. Who overcame he? The beggar.
The conclusion is victory. On whose side? The
King’s. The captive is enriched. On whose side? The
beggar’s. The catastrophe is a nuptial. On whose side?
The King’s— no, on both in one, or one in both. I am
the King, for so stands the comparison; thou the
beggar, for so witnesseth thy lowliness. Shall I command
thy love? I may. Shall I enforce thy love? I could.
Shall I entreat thy love? I will. What shalt thou
exchange for rags? Robes. For tittles? Titles. For thyself?
Me. Thus expecting thy reply, I profane my lips on thy
foot, my eyes on thy picture, and my heart on thy every
part.
Thine, in the dearest design of industry,
Don Adriano de Armado.

lg.l: Thus dost thou hear the Nemean lion roar
’Gainst thee, thou lamb, that standest as his prey.
Submissive fall his princely feet before,
And he from forage will incline to play.
But if thou strive, poor soul, what art thou then?
Food for his rage, repasture for his den.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: What plume of feathers is he that indited this letter?
What vane? What weathercock? Did you ever hear better?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: I am much deceived but I remember the style.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Else your memory is bad, going o’er it erewhile.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: This Armado is a Spaniard that keeps here in court,
A phantasime, a Monarcho, and one that makes sport
To the Prince and his bookmates.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Thou, fellow, a word.
Who gave thee this letter?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: I told you: my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: To whom shouldst thou give it?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: From my lord to my lady.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: From which lord to which lady?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: From my Lord Berowne, a good master of mine,
To a lady of France that he called Rosaline.

sp.speaker: PRINCESS
sp.l: Thou hast mistaken his letter. Come, lords, away.
To Rosaline. Here, sweet, put up this; ’twill be thine another day.

div.stage: The Princess, Katherine, Lords, and Forester exit. Boyet, Rosaline, Maria, and Costard remain.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Who is the shooter? Who is the shooter?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Shall I teach you to know?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: Ay, my continent of beauty.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Why, she that bears the bow.
Finely put off.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: My lady goes to kill horns, but if thou marry,
Hang me by the neck if horns that year miscarry.
Finely put on.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Well, then, I am the shooter.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: And who is your deer?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: If we choose by the horns, yourself come not near.
Finely put on, indeed.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: You still wrangle with her, Boyet, and she strikes at the brow.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: But she herself is hit lower. Have I hit her now?

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.p:
Shall I come upon thee with an old saying,
that was a man when King Pippen of France was a
little boy, as touching the hit it?

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.p:
So I may answer thee with one as old, that was a
woman when Queen Guinover of Britain was a little
wench, as touching the hit it.

sp.speaker: ROSALINE
sp.l: Thou canst not hit it, hit it, hit it,
Thou canst not hit it, my good man.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: An I cannot, cannot, cannot,
An I cannot, another can.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: By my troth, most pleasant. How both did fit it!

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: A mark marvelous well shot, for they both did hit it.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: A mark! O, mark but that mark. “ A mark,” says my lady.
Let the mark have a prick in ’t to mete at, if it may be.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: Wide o’ the bow hand! I’ faith, your hand is out.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: Indeed, he must shoot nearer, or he’ll ne’er hit the clout.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: An if my hand be out, then belike your hand is in.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: Then will she get the upshoot by cleaving the pin.

sp.speaker: MARIA
sp.l: Come, come, you talk greasily. Your lips grow foul.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: She’s too hard for you at pricks, sir. Challenge her to bowl.

sp.speaker: BOYET
sp.l: I fear too much rubbing. Good night, my good owl.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: By my soul, a swain, a most simple clown.
Lord, Lord, how the ladies and I have put him down.
O’ my troth, most sweet jests, most incony vulgar wit,
When it comes so smoothly off, so obscenely, as it were, so fit.
Armado o’ th’ one side, O, a most dainty man!
To see him walk before a lady and to bear her fan.
To see him kiss his hand, and how most sweetly he will swear.
And his page o’ t’ other side, that handful of wit!
Ah heavens, it is a most pathetical nit.
Sola, sola!

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: Enter Dull the Constable, Holofernes the Pedant, and Nathaniel the Curate.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
Very reverend sport, truly, and done in the
testimony of a good conscience.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
The deer was, as you know, sanguis, in
blood, ripe as the pomewater, who now hangeth
like a jewel in the ear of caelo, the sky, the welkin,
the heaven, and anon falleth like a crab on the face
of terra, the soil, the land, the earth.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
Truly, Master Holofernes, the epithets are
sweetly varied, like a scholar at the least. But, sir, I
assure you, it was a buck of the first head.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Sir Nathaniel, haud credo.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p: ’Twas not a haud credo, ’twas a pricket.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Most barbarous intimation! Yet a kind of
insinuation, as it were, in via, in way, of explication;
facere, as it were, replication, or rather, ostentare, to
show, as it were, his inclination, after his undressed,
unpolished, uneducated, unpruned, untrained, or
rather unlettered, or ratherest, unconfirmed fashion,
to insert again my haud credo for a deer.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
I said the deer was not a haud credo, ’twas a
pricket.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p: Twice-sod simplicity, bis coctus!
sp.l: O thou monster ignorance, how deformed dost thou look!

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.l: Sir, he hath never fed of the dainties that are bred in a book.
sp.p:
He hath not eat paper, as it were; he hath not drunk
ink. His intellect is not replenished. He is only an
animal, only sensible in the duller parts.
sp.l: And such barren plants are set before us that we thankful should be—
Which we of taste and feeling are— for those parts that do fructify in us more than he.
For as it would ill become me to be vain, indiscreet, or a fool,
So were there a patch set on learning, to see him in a school.
But omne bene, say I, being of an old father’s mind:
Many can brook the weather that love not the wind.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.l: You two are bookmen. Can you tell me by your wit
What was a month old at Cain’s birth that’s not five weeks old as yet?

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Dictynna, goodman Dull, Dictynna,
goodman Dull.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p: What is “ dictima”?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.l: A title to Phoebe, to Luna, to the moon.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.l: The moon was a month old when Adam was no more.
And raught not to five weeks when he came to fivescore.
Th’ allusion holds in the exchange.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
’Tis true indeed. The collusion holds in the
exchange.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
God comfort thy capacity! I say, th’ allusion
holds in the exchange.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
And I say the pollution holds in the exchange, for
the moon is never but a month old. And I say besides
that, ’twas a pricket that the Princess killed.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Sir Nathaniel, will you hear an extemporal
epitaph on the death of the deer? And, to humor
the ignorant, call I the deer the Princess killed a
pricket.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
Perge, good Master Holofernes, perge, so it
shall please you to abrogate scurrility.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
I will something affect the letter, for it
argues facility.

lg.l: The preyful princess pierced and pricked a pretty pleasing pricket,
Some say a sore, but not a sore till now made sore with shooting.
The dogs did yell. Put “ l” to “ sore,” then sorel jumps from thicket,
Or pricket sore, or else sorel. The people fall a-hooting.
If sore be sore, then “ L” to “ sore” makes fifty sores o’ sorel.
Of one sore I an hundred make by adding but one more “ L.”

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: A rare talent.

sp.speaker: DULL
sp.p:
If a talent be a claw, look how he claws
him with a talent.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
This is a gift that I have, simple, simple—
a foolish extravagant spirit, full of forms,
figures, shapes, objects, ideas, apprehensions, motions,
revolutions. These are begot in the ventricle
of memory, nourished in the womb of pia mater,
and delivered upon the mellowing of occasion. But
the gift is good in those in whom it is acute, and I
am thankful for it.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
Sir, I praise the Lord for you, and so may
my parishioners, for their sons are well tutored by
you, and their daughters profit very greatly under
you. You are a good member of the
commonwealth.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Mehercle, if their sons be ingenious,
they shall want no instruction; if their daughters be
capable, I will put it to them. But Vir sapis qui pauca
loquitur. A soul feminine saluteth us.

div.stage: Enter Jaquenetta and the Clown Costard.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p:
God give you good morrow,
Master Person.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Master Person, quasi pierce one. And
if one should be pierced, which is the one?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p:
Marry, Master Schoolmaster, he that is likeliest
to a hogshead.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Of piercing a hogshead! A good luster
of conceit in a turf of earth; fire enough for a flint,
pearl enough for a swine. ’Tis pretty, it is well.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p:
Good Master Parson, be so
good as read me this letter. It was given me by
Costard, and sent me from Don Armado. I beseech
you, read it.

div.stage: She hands Nathaniel a paper, which he looks at.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.l: Facile precor gelida quando peccas omnia sub umbra.
Ruminat—
sp.p:
and so forth. Ah, good old Mantuan! I may speak of
thee as the traveler doth of Venice:
sp.l: Venetia, Venetia,
Chi non ti vede, non ti pretia.
sp.p:
Old Mantuan, old Mantuan! Who understandeth
thee not, loves thee not. ( He sings.) Ut, re, sol, la,
mi, fa. ( To Nathaniel.) Under pardon, sir, what are
the contents? Or rather, as Horace says in his—
( Looking at the letter.) What, my soul, verses?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Ay, sir, and very learned.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Let me hear a staff, a stanza, a verse,
Lege, domine.

lg.l: If love make me forsworn, how shall I swear to love?
Ah, never faith could hold, if not to beauty vowed!
Though to myself forsworn, to thee I’ll faithful prove.
Those thoughts to me were oaks, to thee like osiers bowed.
Study his bias leaves and makes his book thine eyes,
Where all those pleasures live that art would comprehend.
If knowledge be the mark, to know thee shall suffice.
Well-learnèd is that tongue that well can thee commend.
All ignorant that soul that sees thee without wonder;
Which is to me some praise that I thy parts admire.
Thy eye Jove’s lightning bears, thy voice his dreadful thunder,
Which, not to anger bent, is music and sweet fire.
Celestial as thou art, O, pardon love this wrong,
That sings heaven’s praise with such an earthly tongue.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
You find not the apostrophus, and so
miss the accent. Let me supervise the canzonet.
He takes the paper. Here are only numbers ratified,
but, for the elegancy, facility, and golden cadence of
poesy— caret. Ovidius Naso was the man. And why
indeed “ Naso,” but for smelling out the odoriferous
flowers of fancy, the jerks of invention? Imitari is
nothing: so doth the hound his master, the ape his
keeper, the tired horse his rider.— But damosella
virgin, was this directed to you?

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p:
Ay, sir, from one Monsieur Berowne, one
of the strange queen’s lords.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
I will overglance the superscript: “ To
the snow-white hand of the most beauteous Lady
Rosaline.” I will look again on the intellect of the
letter for the nomination of the party writing to
the person written unto: “ Your Ladyship’s in all
desired employment, Berowne.” Sir Nathaniel, this
Berowne is one of the votaries with the King, and
here he hath framed a letter to a sequent of the
stranger queen’s: which accidentally, or by the way
of progression, hath miscarried.

Trip and go, my sweet. Deliver this paper into the
royal hand of the King. It may concern much. Stay
not thy compliment. I forgive thy duty. Adieu.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.p:
Good Costard, go with me.— Sir, God
save your life.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Have with thee, my girl.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
Sir, you have done this in the fear of God
very religiously; and, as a certain Father saith—

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
Sir, tell not me of the Father. I do fear
colorable colors. But to return to the verses: did
they please you, Sir Nathaniel?

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p: Marvelous well for the pen.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
I do dine today at the father’s of a certain
pupil of mine, where if, before repast, it shall
please you to gratify the table with a grace, I will,
on my privilege I have with the parents of the
foresaid child or pupil, undertake your ben venuto;
where I will prove those verses to be very unlearned,
neither savoring of poetry, wit, nor invention.
I beseech your society.

sp.speaker: NATHANIEL
sp.p:
And thank you too; for society, saith the
text, is the happiness of life.

sp.speaker: HOLOFERNES
sp.p:
And certes the text most infallibly concludes
it. To Dull. Sir, I do invite you too. You shall
not say me nay. Pauca verba. Away! The gentles are
at their game, and we will to our recreation.

div.head: Scene 3
div.stage: Enter Berowne with a paper in his hand, alone.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
The King, he is hunting the deer; I am
coursing myself. They have pitched a toil; I am
toiling in a pitch— pitch that defiles. Defile! A foul
word. Well, “ set thee down, sorrow”; for so they
say the fool said, and so say I, and I the fool. Well
proved, wit. By the Lord, this love is as mad as Ajax.
It kills sheep, it kills me, I a sheep. Well proved
again, o’ my side. I will not love. If I do, hang me. I’
faith, I will not. O, but her eye! By this light, but for
her eye I would not love her; yes, for her two eyes.
Well, I do nothing in the world but lie, and lie in my
throat. By heaven, I do love, and it hath taught me to
rhyme, and to be melancholy. And here is part of my
rhyme, and here my melancholy. Well, she hath one
o’ my sonnets already. The clown bore it, the fool
sent it, and the lady hath it. Sweet clown, sweeter
fool, sweetest lady. By the world, I would not care a
pin, if the other three were in. Here comes one with
a paper. God give him grace to groan.

div.stage: The King entereth with a paper.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.p: Ay me!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.p:
Shot, by heaven! Proceed, sweet
Cupid. Thou hast thumped him with thy birdbolt
under the left pap. In faith, secrets!

sp.speaker: KING

lg.l: So sweet a kiss the golden sun gives not
To those fresh morning drops upon the rose
As thy eyebeams, when their fresh rays have smote
The night of dew that on my cheeks down flows.
Nor shines the silver moon one-half so bright
Through the transparent bosom of the deep
As doth thy face, through tears of mine, give light.
Thou shin’st in every tear that I do weep.
No drop but as a coach doth carry thee;
So ridest thou triumphing in my woe.
Do but behold the tears that swell in me,
And they thy glory through my grief will show.
But do not love thyself; then thou wilt keep
My tears for glasses, and still make me weep.
O queen of queens, how far dost thou excel
No thought can think, nor tongue of mortal tell.

sp.l: How shall she know my griefs? I’ll drop the paper.
Sweet leaves, shade folly. Who is he comes here?
What, Longaville, and reading! Listen, ear.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Now, in thy likeness, one more fool appear!

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: Ay me! I am forsworn.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Why, he comes in like a perjure, wearing papers!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: In love, I hope! Sweet fellowship in shame.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: One drunkard loves another of the name.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: Am I the first that have been perjured so?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: I could put thee in comfort: not by two that I know.
Thou makest the triumviry, the corner-cap of society,
The shape of love’s Tyburn, that hangs up simplicity.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: I fear these stubborn lines lack power to move.

l.q: O sweet Maria, empress of my love—

sp.l: These numbers will I tear and write in prose.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: O, rhymes are guards on wanton Cupid’s hose.
Disfigure not his shop!

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: This same shall go.

lg.l: Did not the heavenly rhetoric of thine eye,
’Gainst whom the world cannot hold argument,
Persuade my heart to this false perjury?
Vows for thee broke deserve not punishment.
A woman I forswore, but I will prove,
Thou being a goddess, I forswore not thee.
My vow was earthly, thou a heavenly love.
Thy grace being gained cures all disgrace in me.
Vows are but breath, and breath a vapor is.
Then thou, fair sun, which on my Earth dost shine,
Exhal’st this vapor-vow; in thee it is.
If broken, then, it is no fault of mine.
If by me broke, what fool is not so wise
To lose an oath to win a paradise?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: This is the liver vein, which makes flesh a deity,
A green goose a goddess. Pure, pure idolatry.
God amend us, God amend. We are much out o’ th’ way.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: By whom shall I send this?— Company? Stay.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: All hid, all hid— an old infant play.
Like a demigod here sit I in the sky,
And wretched fools’ secrets heedfully o’ereye.
More sacks to the mill. O heavens, I have my wish.
Dumaine transformed! Four woodcocks in a dish.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: O most divine Kate!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: O most profane coxcomb!

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: By heaven, the wonder in a mortal eye!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: By Earth, she is not, corporal. There you lie.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: Her amber hairs for foul hath amber quoted.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: An amber-colored raven was well noted.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: As upright as the cedar.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Stoop, I say.
Her shoulder is with child.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: As fair as day.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Ay, as some days, but then no sun must shine.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: O, that I had my wish!

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: And I had mine!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: And mine too, good Lord!

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Amen, so I had mine. Is not that a good word?

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: I would forget her, but a fever she
Reigns in my blood, and will remembered be.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: A fever in your blood? Why, then incision
Would let her out in saucers! Sweet misprision.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: Once more I’ll read the ode that I have writ.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Once more I’ll mark how love can vary wit.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE

lg.l: On a day— alack the day!—
Love, whose month is ever May,
Spied a blossom passing fair,
Playing in the wanton air.
Through the velvet leaves the wind,
All unseen, can passage find;
That the lover, sick to death,
Wished himself the heaven’s breath.
“ Air,” quoth he, “ thy cheeks may blow.
Air, would I might triumph so!”
But, alack, my hand is sworn
Ne’er to pluck thee from thy thorn.
Vow, alack, for youth unmeet,
Youth so apt to pluck a sweet.
Do not call it sin in me
That I am forsworn for thee—
Thou for whom Jove would swear
Juno but an Ethiope were,
And deny himself for Jove,
Turning mortal for thy love.

sp.l: This will I send, and something else more plain
That shall express my true love’s fasting pain.
O, would the King, Berowne, and Longaville
Were lovers too! Ill to example ill
Would from my forehead wipe a perjured note,
For none offend where all alike do dote.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: Dumaine, thy love is far from charity,
That in love’s grief desir’st society.
You may look pale, but I should blush, I know,
To be o’er-heard and taken napping so.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: To Longaville. Come, sir, you blush! As his, your case is such.
You chide at him, offending twice as much.
You do not love Maria? Longaville
Did never sonnet for her sake compile,
Nor never lay his wreathèd arms athwart
His loving bosom to keep down his heart?
I have been closely shrouded in this bush
And marked you both, and for you both did blush.
I heard your guilty rhymes, observed your fashion,
Saw sighs reek from you, noted well your passion.
“ Ay, me!” says one. “ O Jove!” the other cries.
One, her hairs were gold, crystal the other’s eyes.
To Longaville. You would for paradise break faith and troth,
To Dumaine. And Jove, for your love, would infringe an oath.
What will Berowne say when that he shall hear
Faith infringed, which such zeal did swear?
How will he scorn, how will he spend his wit!
How will he triumph, leap, and laugh at it!
For all the wealth that ever I did see,
I would not have him know so much by me.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Now step I forth to whip hypocrisy.
Ah, good my liege, I pray thee pardon me.
Good heart, what grace hast thou thus to reprove
These worms for loving, that art most in love?
Your eyes do make no coaches; in your tears
There is no certain princess that appears.
You’ll not be perjured, ’tis a hateful thing!
Tush, none but minstrels like of sonneting!
But are you not ashamed? Nay, are you not,
All three of you, to be thus much o’ershot?
To Longaville. You found his mote, the King your mote did see,
But I a beam do find in each of three.
O, what a scene of fool’ry have I seen,
Of sighs, of groans, of sorrow, and of teen!
O me, with what strict patience have I sat,
To see a king transformèd to a gnat!
To see great Hercules whipping a gig,
And profound Solomon to tune a jig,
And Nestor play at pushpin with the boys,
And critic Timon laugh at idle toys.
Where lies thy grief, O tell me, good Dumaine?
And gentle Longaville, where lies thy pain?
And where my liege’s? All about the breast!
A caudle, ho!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Too bitter is thy jest.
Are we betrayed thus to thy overview?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Not you to me, but I betrayed by you.
I, that am honest, I, that hold it sin
To break the vow I am engagèd in.
I am betrayed by keeping company
With men like you, men of inconstancy.
When shall you see me write a thing in rhyme?
Or groan for Joan? or spend a minute’s time
In pruning me? When shall you hear that I
Will praise a hand, a foot, a face, an eye,
A gait, a state, a brow, a breast, a waist,
A leg, a limb—

div.stage: Enter Jaquenetta, with a paper, and Clown Costard.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Soft, whither away so fast?
A true man, or a thief, that gallops so?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: I post from love. Good lover, let me go.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.l: God bless the King.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: What present hast thou there?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: Some certain treason.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: What makes treason here?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: Nay, it makes nothing, sir.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: If it mar nothing neither,
The treason and you go in peace away together.

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.l: I beseech your Grace, let this letter be read.
Our person misdoubts it. ’Twas treason, he said.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Berowne, read it over.
Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: JAQUENETTA
sp.l: Of Costard.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Where hadst thou it?

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.p: Of Dun Adramadio, Dun Adramadio.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: How now, what is in you? Why dost thou tear it?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: A toy, my liege, a toy. Your Grace needs not fear it.

sp.speaker: LONGAVILLE
sp.l: It did move him to passion, and therefore let’s hear it.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: It is Berowne’s writing, and here is his name.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: Ah, you whoreson loggerhead, you were born to do me shame.—
Guilty, my lord, guilty. I confess, I confess.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: That you three fools lacked me fool to make up the mess.
He, he, and you— and you, my liege— and I
Are pickpurses in love, and we deserve to die.
O, dismiss this audience, and I shall tell you more.

sp.speaker: DUMAINE
sp.l: Now the number is even.

sp.speaker: BEROWNE
sp.l: True, true, we are four.
Pointing to Jaquenetta and Costard. Will these turtles be gone?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Hence, sirs. Away.

sp.speaker: COSTARD
sp.l: Walk aside the true folk, and let the traitors stay.

lg.l: Sweet lords, sweet lovers, O, let us embrace.
As true we are as flesh and blood can be.
The sea will ebb and flow, heaven show his face;
Young blood doth not obey an old decree.
We cannot cross the cause why we were born;
Therefore of all hands must we be forsworn.
What, did these rent lines show some love of thine?
Did they, quoth you? Who sees the heavenly Rosaline
That, like a rude and savage man of Ind
At the first op’ning of the gorgeous East,
Bows not his vassal head and, strucken blind,
Kisses the base ground with obedient breast?
What peremptory eagle-sighted eye
Dares look upon the heaven of her brow
That is not blinded by her majesty?
What zeal, what fury, hath inspired thee now?
My love, her mistress, is a gracious moon,
She an attending star scarce seen a light.
My eyes are then no eyes, nor I Berowne.
O, but for my love, day would turn to night!
Of all complexions the culled sovereignty
Do meet as at a fair in her fair cheek.
Where several worthies make one dignity,
Where nothing wants that want itself doth seek.
Lend me the flourish of all gentle tongues—
Fie, painted rhetoric! O, she needs it not!
To things of sale a seller’s praise belongs.
She passes praise. Then praise too short doth blot.
A withered hermit, fivescore winters worn,
Might shake off fifty, looking in her eye.
Beauty doth varnish age, as if newborn,
And gives the crutch the cradle’s infancy.
O, ’tis the sun that maketh all things shine!
By heaven, thy love is black as ebony.
Is ebony like her? O word divine!
A wife of such wood were felicity.
O, who can give an oath? Where is a book,
That I may swear beauty doth beauty lack
If that she learn not of her eye to look?
No face is fair that is not full so black.
O, paradox! Black is the badge of hell,
The hue of dungeons and the school of night,
